bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] removing help button from TrayDialog is difficult

long_desc.thetext:
3.3
It is very difficultto create a subclass of TrayDialog that does not have a help button. You need to override createButtonBar and not only implement the code in TrayDialog but Dialog as well - TrayDialog calls super. It would be nice to simply override createHelp* and if these methods return null but this currenty isn't possible because layout is attached to the returned control without a null check.
Curtis, do you want to take a look or shall I?
You can override isHelpAvailable(), return false, and it won't create the help control.
I assume this answer is sufficient, Kim? Please reopen if it's not.

bug.short_desc: @annotation compilation problem

long_desc.thetext:
you didn't include the declaration of the annotation type - but i made one up. The bug here is that the hierarchy is more than 2 deep. You have A > B > C. If you have A > C (ie. C extends A directly) then it would work without an error.
I've committed a testcase and the fix - thanks for supplying a minimal set of files that show the problem.
fix available in latest dev build.

bug.short_desc: [implementation] hashCode/equals of TextEditorSavable must not change

long_desc.thetext: I found a case where the result of hashCode and equals for AbstractTextEditor#TextEditorSaveable can change. If a compare editor and a text editor are open and have equal saveables, closing the text editor will cause its document to go away. This will change the result of the equals method and cause the workbench to prompt with the wrong message and then throw an assert exception.

Created an attachment (id=56472) Patch with potential solution
I have attached a patch with a potential solution. It records the document the first time it is obtained. This fix requires that the document be available the first time it is obtained and I don;t know if this is true all the time (it was in my tests). It also assumes that the document will not change while the editor is opened. If the document of the editor can change, then the editor would need to fire save lifecycle events to remove this saveable and add a new one for the new document.
This may lead to lost data. Can this be fixed for the next I build?

>This may lead to lost data. Can this be fixed for the next I build? Do you have steps? I wasn't able to reproduce it.
I think I fixed the problem but since I don't have steps it is hard to be sure.

> Do you have steps? I wasn't able to reproduce it.
I don't, Michael?

The steps are:
1) Open editor A on file X 2) Open editor B on file X (both editor must use file buffers) 3) Dirty one of the editors (both should appear dirty) 4) Close editor A. Since this was the first one open, the saveable for this editor was used in the reference count hashmap of the workbench. 5) Close editor B. The resulting prompt should indicate that this is the last occurance of the buffer but I was prompted indicating that the buffer was open elsewhere.
If you like, I can verify your fix since I need to retest the fix for bug 167607 anyway.
Boris, the same problem happens to the compare editor's savable. We need a solution that doesn't hold on to savables of closed editors.

BTW, in comment #1 it was stated "It also assumes that the document will not change while the editor is opened."
I'm pretty sure this is not always true for all editors in Eclipse in general, and am pretty sure it is not part of the "Editor API contract" -- so to now require it, would be a subtle API change.
Dani, do you have an opinion or insights on this "changing document" issue?
Is this even relevant anymore? Or is the attached patch obsolete?

>BTW, in comment #1 it was stated "It also assumes that the document will not >change while the editor is opened." That was a wrong comment: it can and in fact does change, e.g. if the editor is reused. This is handled in the doSetInput(...) method were the life-cycle listener is notified and a new savable created.
> Or is the attached patch obsolete? The patch is rather a workaround and I released something along that line until the real problem (see comment 6) is fixed).

Created an attachment (id=56645) Patch to decouple saveable from editor
One solution that Boris suggested to me was to decouple the saveable form the editor. This should work since the editors must react to saves made from other sources anyway. The patch I have attached decouples the saveable from the text editor. One requirement was to use the same saveable from the compare editor and this is possible due to the reason I stated above (i.e. internally I use a saveable that handles all the compare stuff but I present the shared document saveable to the workbench).
For the hashCode and equals method, the editor input is used. There is, however, one outstanding issue. The saveable also needs to ensure that the document provider used by two sveables would be the same. This is problematic because document providers can be wrapped and I couldn't find API to access the wrapped provider (so, I think API would need to be added to document providers to make this work).
Thoughts?
Document providers are not just wrapped but can be completely different and still use the same file buffer/document.

I didn't look exactly how the UI code is implemented but I would expect (and that is important for compatibility reasons) that when I execute save on editor X it will trigger EditorPart.doSave(...) and documentProvider.saveDocument(...). While the editor (e.g. Java editor) can react to the changes made this way it may loose important functionality/checks that are done in editor.save or its version of the document provider, e.g. organize import on save.
What about decoupling the savable that does the work form the object that is used to identify whether two savables are equal?

In regards to the document provider wrapping, what I think would be required is API on a document provider that would be able to perform the proper test (i.e. API that asks the question "would you return the same file buffer as this other document provider").
In regards to the non-deterministic save behavior depending on the target of the save command, another approach would be to incorporate save participants at the file buffer level. Or, to put it another way, if I have said that I want to format Java code on save, wouldn't I want this to work if I saved from a compare editor as well?

>if I have said that I want to >format Java code on save, wouldn't I want this to work if I saved from a >compare editor as well? I think this is another discussion: you would like to have *all* Java editor functionality and hence also the organize import on save. However, if I open a *.java file in the simple text editor I (i.e. me) would not want these side-effects.

Sounds reasonable. A possible solution then would be for the Java editor to subclass the SynchronizedDocumentSaveable and extends it to perform the additional behavior. Having such a subclass would then potentially make that behavior available to the Java compare viewer as well.

Sorry but I don't like the document provider based solution. What speaks against the current solution but with a method to return an object used as comparable? This object can be independent of the editor, the editor input and also the document provider. There would be no tweaks needed by Platform UI to make sure not to hold on to a disposed object any longer.
Personally even in the compare editor (e.g. while committing) I would probably not want to do anything else than a pure save.

The issue I see is that what you are saying is that the two Saveables we are talking about are not really equal. Based on what you said, if I close a dirty Java editor on a file that is open in another editor, if the prompt were to truly reflect the situation it would read something like "This file is opened in another editor so if you choose not to save here, you will not loose changes but you will also not get the behavior related to the Java editor such as format on save". Obviously, this is an exaggeration to make a point but, I'm concerned that users who see the current prompt would assume there was no difference between choosing No and then saving it elsewhere or choosing Yes.
As for your suggestion of have API that returns a comparable, what's the difference between that and writing a Saveable that null's it reference to the editor when the editor is closed but keeps the hashCode and equals consistent? I guess it would make the separation more explicit but that's about it as far as I can see.

>As for your suggestion of have API that returns a comparable, what's the >difference between that and writing a Saveable that null's it reference to the >editor when the editor is closed but keeps the hashCode and equals consistent? The object would not be needed if Platform UI would correctly remove its reference to the saveable that the client marked as being closed. If that can't be done then the new object/key is cleaner and makes debugging and leak hunting easier i.e. if you close the editor its savable is gone too.

>"This file is opened >in another editor so if you choose not to save here, you will not loose changes >but you will also not get the behavior related to the Java editor such as >format on save".
This is not only true for the Java Editor but also the Compare Editor i.e. if you close the Compare Editor you will loose the ability to compare the dirty file with another one and updating the current file with from the other one in that compare editor.
Maybe the dialog should indeed point the user to this. I think changing the implementation to only treat similar editors with same model as being equal would be too restricting.
What's the state of this for M5?

(In reply to comment #16) > Sorry but I don't like the document provider based solution. What speaks > against the current solution but with a method to return an object used as > comparable? This object can be independent of the editor, the editor input and > also the document provider. There would be no tweaks needed by Platform UI to > make sure not to hold on to a disposed object any longer.
Sorry, but I don't understand how this would work. To me, it all makes sense when there is one saveable that is shared by the Java editor and the Compare editor. I'm confused as to what you mean by a comparable object, could you sketch the API you have in mind?
In the case of Save All, what do you expect to happen if the same file is open in both editors? One will be saved before the other, so depending on the order you will get format on save or not.

I should add that ISaveablesSource and Saveable are both @since 3.2, not 3.3, so any change would have to be binary upwards compatible.
As for the dialog, I'm not convinced that we need additional information in there.

After releasing a fix similar to comment 1 (see my comment 9) I am no longer able to reproduce the problem indicated in comment 5. I think the main problem was caused because I was sending wrong life-cycle events (see bug 170184) and that is now fixed.
Boris, I think my suggested solution is not needed. The reason why the savables list held on to my editor (the source) was caused by bug 170184.
>In the case of Save All, what do you expect to happen if the same file is open >in both editors? That is indeed a problem and maybe we need to back off treating Java Editor (CompilationUnitDocumentProvider) and Text editor (TextFileDocumentProvider) the same.
Closing (or was there anything left to do, Dani?)

Not what this PR regards. Just a hint to Michael: I enhanced my code with a method to disconnect the editor when the editor closes. This breaks the link from the savable which is still used as key in the SavableList ref count map. This way many objects (like actions) can be freed.
Of course the question whether we should treat Java and Text editor's document provider remains. For now I'd say we leave it as is since we may "only" loose the post-save operations which is not lost work.

attachment.desc: Patch to decouple saveable from editor

bug.short_desc: [GlobalActions] Close Many dialog

long_desc.thetext: It would be nice to have a facility for closing many open files, selectively. Sometimes I open many files to make a change and would like to close selected ones after I am finished. A dialog could pop up showing all open files with checkboxes beside each name. Those selected would be closed when the dialog was dismissed.
Assigning to component owner PW

bug.short_desc: Adding Data element with duplicate aggregation expression gets identity mixup with existing Data element

long_desc.thetext: Data element added to a group for aggregation that has the same aggregation expression as another data element in another group in the same table has its name set to the same value as the pre-existing data element (identity mixup).

Steps to reproduce: 1. Open attached report design 2. Drag Data element to "Amount Cell" next to "Date Total: " label 3. When "New Data Item" dialog pops up, enter "Date Total" for name, Decimal for data type, and enter "Total.sum(row["AMOUNT"])" as the expression. For "aggregate on" option, select "PaymentDate", which is the outer grouping. 4. Click OK 5. bug.short_desc: .cvsignore ignored

long_desc.thetext: I created a local directory that I do not want to commit (it's a symbolic link to another directory that is already checked in), so I added it to the .cvsignore file via right-click -> "Add to .cvsignore". But now this folder keeps showing up in the "Synchronize" view, where Eclipse suggests deleting the contents of this dir! I've refreshed and restarted Eclipse, to no avail...

This is a bit of a tricky issue which stems from the fact that Eclipse doesn't recognize symlinks. The CVS plug-in sees the directory as being mapped to CVS since it contains CVS meta-data. This leads the CVS plug-in to believe that the folder has been explicitly shared which overrides the entry in the .cvsignore file. If you could use an Eclipse link, instead of a symlink, the CVS plug-in would properly ignore the folder (since Eclipse links are always ignored).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 79869 ***

bug.short_desc: [Launcher] Eclipse won't launch in Mac OS X 10.5

long_desc.thetext:
+++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #169337 +++
Build ID: 3.2
Steps To Reproduce: Note: You need to be a ADC Select or Premier member to reproduce this.
1. Install a developer seed of Mac OS X 10.5 (9A321 is the latest developer seed) 2. Launch Eclipse 3.2 or later
Result: an alert appears indicating that Java failed with exit 1.
More information: This is happening because the platform launcher code is checking whether or not argv[1] begins with "-psn_". Changes in application launching in 10.5 removed this argument, and as a result the application doesn't check for the correct startup parameters in its Info.plist file. Startup.jar can't be found, so Eclipse fails to launch.
The existence of the '-psn_' argument is an undocumented implementation detail, and shouldn't be relied upon.

bug.short_desc: [PerspectiveBar] Perspective tab should use more of its available space

long_desc.thetext:
When you have several perspectives but the perspective tab cannot show them all, it tends to leave space between the last perspective name and the ">>" pulldown with the hidden perspective names. The amount of blank space left can be quite a lot, which aside from looking odd, and seems a waste of the opportunity to show at least part of the next name.
It seems there is a minimum width before it doesn't bother showing the tab, but this minimum is quite long and is clearly different than the strategy for view tabs. Since people have few perspectives which are often fairly uniquely named, the minimum text can be quite small, so this empty space could be put to good use.

Kevin, do you think that we can 'normalize' tab management so that we have the same strategies for both (even if the impl's are different for each)? We seem to face the same issues for the Perspective Switcher, TabFolders & (view) toolbars
When is it 'too small' (i.e. needs a dropdown) How do we optimize the space (so that it isn't 'too small' too often)
Seems like these should all be related somehow...comments?

bug.short_desc: FrameworkEvent of type ERROR fired when starting an INSTALLED bundle

long_desc.thetext:
From equinox newgroup posting
http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=2543&group=eclipse.technology.equinox#2543
Hi all,
As mentioned in a previous post, I am having some trouble when trying to install and start bundles in 3.3M4. For example, if I install both equinox.common and equinox.registry using BundleContext.installBundle, then start them using Bundle.start(Bundle.START_TRANSIENT), I get an exception:
org.osgi.framework.BundleException: State change in progress for bundle "reference:file:C:\tools\cygwin\home\jsankey\repo\pulse\trunk\plugins\internal\org.eclipse.equinox.common_3.3.0.v20061117-3.3M4.jar" by thread "main". at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.beginStateChange(AbstractBundle.java:1141) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.resume(AbstractBundle.java:347) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.Framework.resumeBundle(Framework.java:1115) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.PackageAdminImpl.resumeBundles(PackageAdminImpl.java:255) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.PackageAdminImpl.doResolveBundles(PackageAdminImpl.java:225) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.PackageAdminImpl.resolveBundles(PackageAdminImpl.java:173) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker(BundleHost.java:301) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.start(AbstractBundle.java:260) at com.zutubi.pulse.plugins.DefaultPluginManager.loadInternalPlugins(DefaultPluginManager.java:91) at com.zutubi.pulse.plugins.DefaultPluginManager.init(DefaultPluginManager.java:40) ...
Tracing the code, this feels like a bug. If a bundle is started when in the INSTALLED state (i.e. not resolved), and a few other (seemingly common) conditions are met, the above occurs. The bundle is already undergoing state change by being started, but the resolve->resume process tries to mark it for state change again. I can overcome this by forcing the bundles to be resolved (in any of a few different ways) before I start them.
I also poked into the EclipseStarter and ConfigurationActivator to try and understand why they are unaffected. In both cases, they avoid the issue by a call to PackageAdmin.refreshPackages in between installing and starting bundles (so bundles are resolved before start is called). In fact, the code in these two classes is pretty much cut-and-pasted and, to quote a comment, "a hack". This arises as the refresh is asynchronous but in these cases the code forces it to be synchronous by waiting for FrameworkEvent.PACKAGES_REFRESHED. All this seems quite complicated for what ought to be a basic use case: installing and starting bundles. In my case I am currently just calling PackageAdmin.resolveBundles, but do wonder when a package refresh is necessary? My reading of the spec suggests that it is only important when some bundles are uninstalled, which can happen in the configurator case but not (as yet) in my own case.
Cheers, Jason

Created an attachment (id=56488) patch
I can reproduce the error, but I only see a FrameworkEvent of type ERROR getting fired (and written to the log). The exception is not propagated to the caller of Bundle.start.
This patch prevents the FrameworkEvent by checking to see if the bundle is currently changing state by the current thread when doing a normal resolve (not refreshPackage). If the bundle is currently changing state (i.e. being started) then we do not attempt to resume the bundle.
Released fix for 3.3 M5.
Setting state to FIXED.

bug.short_desc: setTabList should handle a null to reference parent

long_desc.thetext:
I have a composite with several children, but the composite itself also can take the focus. There are some buttons at the top that work similarly to a tool bar, and there are some other buttons that I would like to receive the focus AFTER the parent itself. In other words, I'd like the focus to go "Button 1, button 2, parent, button 3, button 4," but I do not believe this is supported, unless I'm mistaken.
I propose allowing a null element in the array argument to setTabList() that represents the parent or allowing a reference to the parent instead. Or, possibly, for there to be a function either as callback or as a listener that takes as input the last focus object and returns the next one.

If a composite takes part in traversal, focus goes to it before any of the children. This makes sense for controls such as tab folders that have child controls but also take part in focus traversal (ie. focus goes to the tab, then into the page).
I believe you can get when you want without new API using the SWT.Traverse event (but you will need to add it to every button and the parent). It will take a bunch of code that manages the traversal yourself. Ping this bug report on Monday and I will have a go at writing example code.

That seems awfully messy in order to just set the order, although I concede that wanting the parent to be in the middle is unusual. Still, I could certainly see several cases where a parent composite might want to go last instead of first, and allowing that to be specified with the setTabList() method seems logical.
But you're right, using the traverse listener could totally work. I think I see how to do it. Set doit to false and just call setFocus() on the next button in the chain? It could certainly work, although it would be odd to have to modify the button 4 code if I wated to add a button 5 that has an unrelated function. Doesn't seem like that's good OO design.
This is that Monday ping. Could I go ahead and see your answer?
Wow. That's even uglier than I thought it was going to be, which makes me believe all the more that it'd be nice if SWT allowed you to choose where the parent belonged in the tab order.

The parent belongs first in the tab order. You could also fix this by adding another composite between B3 and B4 (ie. another widget in the children list that is in the correct spot). Certainly, this is safer and way less work. Since I don't know what your widget looks like, this may not be possible.

bug.short_desc: Consistency: use of BOLD

long_desc.thetext:
A consistency item on our 3.3 list is to look at various visual markup. This bug report is to track our use of bold.
1) We need to decide on the rules for use of bold.
I will claim that bold should be used, and only used, to denote something has changed. Things that use bold for other purposes should use a different markup. Things that use something else to denote new or changed should use bold.
TBD
2) This bug will act as the parent for individual bugs which do not follow the consistency recommendation.

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] WildcardBinding.boundCheck coding error

long_desc.thetext: For multiple bounds, returns true if only one of the bounds is satisfied rather than requiring all of the bounds to be satisfied. The comment indicates that all of the bounds must be satisfied, and JLS3 15.12.2.7, p. 465 seems to indicate that as well.
I think we have another bug for this. Need to isolate a simple testcase.

(In reply to comment #3)
This test case above is also correctly handled with 3.2.0.
It looks like the problem is just with the comment.
x.boundCheck(y) apparently means y is compatible with x, in which case y must be compatible with at least one of the bounds of x, not with all of them as the comment states.
Yes, this is my opinion too. For wildcards, the check is easier, since it relies on the fact that no offending type could be built anyway (and fed to the wildcard).

bug.short_desc: Dialog fonts should be used in TPTP preference pages

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. go to Window > Preferences in eclipse 2. type "font" in the filter text field 3. select "Colors and Fonts" in the tree 4. type "dialog" in the filter text field on the right side 5. select "Dialog Font" 6. click Change and choose a different dialog font size, such as 16 7. click OK to save the preferences 8. go back to the preferences and select preference groups such as "Ant" and "Help", and notice the pages all use the new dialog font size 9. Now go to any of the preference pages under "Analysis", "Profiling", or "Test". Notice that most or all of the fonts are not using the Dialog font
More information: Dialog font is the expected font for Eclipse preference pages. Notice that preference pages originating from TPTP in the standard TPTP workspace are the only ones that don't follow this convention.
The solution is easy. At the end of the createControl() method, call this:
Dialog.applyDialogFont(topControl);
where "topControl" is the top most control on the preference page. This method will recursively ensure that every child of that control also uses the Dialog font.
cannot be contained in 4.4i1
Paul, please resolve this defect and review the code changes with Eugene.

Created an attachment (id=62968) patch
Patch which adjusts the font in the preferences pages accordingly
Searched the CVS for plugins that contribute preference pages ('org.eclipse.ui.preferencePages' extension point). Added the code suggested in comment 1 to all preference pages ( Dialog.applyDialogFont(topControl); )

org.eclipse.hyades.test.tools.ui org.eclipse.hyades.test.ui org.eclipse.hyades.test.ui.extensions org.eclipse.tptp.test.samples.

bug.short_desc: highlighting preference changes not taken effect after save as

long_desc.thetext:
using wtp 2.0 1/3/07
1. open a file in an sse editor 2. change syntax highlighting color preference and notice color changes 3. save file as something else 4. change syntax highlighting color preference and notice color changes do not take into effect till you close/reopen editor
*** Bug 140482 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 140482 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=57398) sse.ui.jsp.ui.javascript.ui.patch
When a multipage editor such as the xml editor is created or when save as is performed, the viewer configuration is uninstalled and reinstalled. This means the highlighter is uninstalled and then reinstalled. Which means the line style providers are uninstalled and then reinstalled.
During line style provider's install, there's a check to see if it's already been installed. If it has, it wont register a preference listener. Problem is that during release, the isInstalled flag wasnt being set back to false. So reinstallation in the line style provider was being skipped. So no preference listener was being added back in.
The fix is to set isInstalled to false during release.

Created an attachment (id=57398) sse.ui.jsp.ui.javascript.ui.patch
When a multipage editor such as the xml editor is created or when save as is performed, the viewer configuration is uninstalled and reinstalled. This means the highlighter is uninstalled and then reinstalled. Which means the line style providers are uninstalled and then reinstalled.
During line style provider's install, there's a check to see if it's already been installed. If it has, it wont register a preference listener. Problem is that during release, the isInstalled flag wasnt being set back to false. So reinstallation in the line style provider was being skipped. So no preference listener was being added back in.
The fix is to set isInstalled to false during release.

bug.short_desc: [UI] Better understanding of PDE documentation

long_desc.thetext:
1) Combine the Platform Plug-in Developer Guide with Plug-in Development Environment Guide into one Eclipse TOC entry "Plugin Development". That way programmers will immediately grasp that plugin development is supported in two ways in Eclipse.
2) Put the following excellent text posted by John Arthorne onto eclipse.platform at the introduction page for the combined document. ---- Platform Plug-in Developer Guide is the documentation about the APIs provided by the platform: extension points, javadoc, and other developer documentation about how to extend the platform.
Plug-in Development Environment Guide is the user documentation for the plug-in development tools (PDE). How to use the plugin development wizards, etc.
The topics may seem similar, but are really orthogonal. You can write plugins for the platform without using any of the tooling provided by PDE. Likewise, you can use PDE to write plugins for something other than the platform (plugins for JDT, for example, or even pure OSGi bundles that have no Eclipse awareness). -----

bug.short_desc: Problems with eclipse core expressions and loading of testers on demand

long_desc.thetext:
This is related to the fix that was implemented for the following bug:
Eclipse Core Expressions Property Testers not loaded on demand https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=130338
I am opening this against JDT-UI since that's how the original bug was targeted, but please retarget as appropriate. I couldn't find an appropriate bucket for the core expressions plugin.
The fix to the above bug made it possible to trigger property tester loading if both the test expression and the evaluation context set a flag to true. The problem is that when you use a "With" expression a child evaluation context is created, but the value of the magic flag is not copied into the child evaluation context. This makes it impossible to use enablement expressions of the following form without resorting to partial solution hacks (such as marking the plugin implementing the property tester for auto-load):
<enablement> <with variable="my.var"> <test property="my.prop" value="some.value" forcePluginActivation="true"/> </with> </enablement>
The fix is very simple (I will attach a patch) and we would really like to see this resolved in 3.2.2 as it's affecting our ability to ship certain features on that platform.

Created an attachment (id=56505) Patch
There were two possible solutions:
1) Copy the value of the flag from parent context when child context is constructed.
2) Always delegate to the parent context if it exists.
I wasn't sure which one made the most architectural sense, so I went with #1 for this patch which feels a bit safer.
It looks like IterateExpression handles this by delegating to the parent, so perhaps that's the right solution for WithExpression as well...
Dirk, this looks like a 3.2.2 fix and would best be done today.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 155685 ***

bug.short_desc: Export->Deployable Plugins does not respect compiler settings

long_desc.thetext:
build N20061220-0010, 3.3.0
1. Go to Prefences->Java->Compiler->Errors/Warnings 2. Change some settings, for example, turn off the Generic Types warnings 3. Take a plugin that would otherwise generate these warnings. You will not see any in the Problems view (correct) 4. Pick File->Export->Deployable Plugins
The export will produce log files with these exact warnings in them.
Since I turned off these warnings as a preference because I don't want to see them, I shouldn't have them flagged in export (I already said I don't care about them). This makes checking the export process problematic because you need to wade through the warnings which you know you don't care about.
Moving to PDE UI because pde build is not workspace aware and should be told by PDE UI what those values are.
pascal, how/where can we pass you that information?

You could set the property javacWarnings.<libName> in the build.properties. The same approach could be applied to file encodings.
http://help.eclipse.org/help32/topic/org.eclipse.pde.doc.user/reference/pde_feature_generating_build.htm

We can't really do that. Well we can, but it would be extremely messy. We shouldn't pollute/touch the build.properties files for the workspace plug-ins with all these compiler flags upon exporting. It's a no go.
is there a programmatic/dynamic way in which we can pass that information to the build process?

There is not currently any other way to pass this information.
Except that this is written to the javaCompiler.<library>.args file that we generate. If you really wanted to you could go modify that file after script generation.

bug.short_desc: [Forms] FormText does not have the same cursor and selection behavior as Text widget

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1.Place focus on FormText 2.Cursor to indicate focus is missing on Windows 3.Keyboard can not be used to select text but mouse will select text
More information: This is an accessibility problem as it presents different behavior for text within a view. FormText and Text are used so that screen readers can read focusible elements

Created an attachment (id=56507) Cursor missing from FormText, no keyboard selection
No focus cursor is displayed when the FormText widget has focus. Text widget displays focus cursor No keyboard selection in FormText widget Text widget allows both mouse and keyboard selection of text.
Adam can you take a look, I would only fix this if it is low risk.

The intent of FormText is to allow inline hyperlinks that will act as tab stops while the static text inside them will not. Attempting to add keyboard selection support in tandem with this functionality would not be trivial.
As for showing a cursor position on focus, this poses the same problem. It is difficult to show a cursor position without compromising the functionality of the hyperlink tab stops.
The idea behind FormText is really to get a web browser look and feel inside a rich client application. I just experimented and found that static text in IE7 actually behaves exactly like form text. Clicking does not show you a cursor location and you cannot use the keyboard to select static text. Firefox is a little bit nicer in this respect. It will not show you the cursor position either, but it does know where the cursor is and will let you use the keyboard to select text.
Also, my understanding is that screen readers should not rely on focusable elements to know what to read. Generally only input is focusable, and this behaviour would cause the reader to miss all informational text.
Tagging this as an enhancement for future consideration.

bug.short_desc: [AST] character position range wrong for super method call with type arguments

long_desc.thetext:
The AST for a super method call with type arguments has incorrect start/end positions for the SuperMethodInvocation node. If there are no explicit type arguments, then the SuperMethodInvocation node begins at the beginning of the super token (as it should); if there are explict type arguments on the method name, then the SuperMethodInvocation node's character range begins on the < token that starts the type arguments, rather than at the beginning of the super token.
TREES FOR class A { int i = super.m(); } ECLIPSE AST 0) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit 0 30 1) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.TypeDeclaration 0 30 interface = false 2) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 6 1 identifier = A 3) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.FieldDeclaration 10 18 4) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.PrimitiveType 10 3 primitiveTypeCode = int 5) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 14 13 extraDimensions = 0 6) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 14 1 identifier = i 7) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SuperMethodInvocation 18 9 8) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 24 1 identifier = m
TREES FOR class A { int i = super.<T>m(); } ECLIPSE AST 0) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit 0 33 1) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.TypeDeclaration 0 33 interface = false 2) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 6 1 identifier = A 3) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.FieldDeclaration 10 21 4) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.PrimitiveType 10 3 primitiveTypeCode = int 5) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 14 16 extraDimensions = 0 6) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 14 1 identifier = i 7) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SuperMethodInvocation 24 6 8) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleType 25 1 9) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 25 1 identifier = T 10) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 27 1 identifier = m
+1 for 3.2.2 if it has no bad effect for JDT/UI. Olivier - is it really that important for 3.2.2 ? Is the fix trivial ?
To clarify, besides being wrong, why is this considered so bad it needs to go in the 3.2.2 update ? Can't it only get fixed for 3.3 ?
+ 1 for the fix. The AST rewriter replies on the correct source ranges.
Created an attachment (id=56578) Proposed fix
Created an attachment (id=56579) Regression tests
Created an attachment (id=56580) Proposed fix for 3.2 maintenance branch
Released for 3.3M5. Regression test added in org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.dom.ASTConverter15Test#test0234

bug.short_desc: infix operators are not always flattened

long_desc.thetext:
In the Java AST, the InfixExpression AST node is allowed to have more than 2 operands, where the one operator is applied to all. However, this flattening is not always performed. See the trees below. A - operation followed by many + operations is not flattened, whereas many + followed by a - is flattened. (I actually found it a pain to coerce my parser to reproduce this - it would have been easier just to compare the current operator with the operator from the previous (LH) operand - if the same, combine; if not, make a new Infix node)
TREES FOR class A { int i = 1 - 2 + 3 + 4 + 5; int j = 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 - 5; } ECLIPSE AST 0) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.CompilationUnit 0 65 1) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.TypeDeclaration 0 65 interface = false 2) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 6 1 identifier = A 3) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.FieldDeclaration 10 26 4) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.PrimitiveType 10 3 primitiveTypeCode = int 5) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 14 21 extraDimensions = 0 6) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 14 1 identifier = i 7) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 18 17 operator = + 8) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 18 13 operator = + 9) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 18 9 operator = + 10) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 18 5 operator = - 11) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 18 1 token = 1 12) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 22 1 token = 2 13) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 26 1 token = 3 14) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 30 1 token = 4 15) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 34 1 token = 5 16) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.FieldDeclaration 37 26 17) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.PrimitiveType 37 3 primitiveTypeCode = int 18) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.VariableDeclarationFragment 41 21 extraDimensions = 0 19) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.SimpleName 41 1 identifier = j 20) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 45 17 operator = - 21) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.InfixExpression 45 13 operator = + 22) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 45 1 token = 1 23) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 49 1 token = 2 24) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 53 1 token = 3 25) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 57 1 token = 4 26) class org.eclipse.jdt.core.dom.NumberLiteral 61 1 token = 5
For 1 - 2 + 3 + 4 + 5, are you expecting to get an infix expression with: -left: an infix expression that contains (1 - 2) - rigth: 3 - extended operands: 4, 5 ?

(In reply to comment #1) > For 1 - 2 + 3 + 4 + 5, are you expecting to get an infix expression with: > -left: an infix expression that contains (1 - 2) > - rigth: 3 > - extended operands: 4, 5 > ?
Yes (and sorry I missed this comment when it was originally made).

This problem was found by Duwayne on the 4.4.0 driver.
The NPE exception (see the stack trace at the end of the comment) happens after you restart the workbench and try to view in the Test navigator existing testcases created in advance.
I tried Manual, AGR, and URL tests and for all I get the same behaviour.
I was able to reproduce it on 4.3 also.
I found that the NPE happens for those mementos that don't have "nodeKind" attribute on the root element.
Here is an example with not null and null case.

<childNode nodeKind="testCaseNode" type="org.eclipse.hyades.test.http.junit.testCase" uriFragment="C2DDBDF65C2703BADCA880F09D1B11DB"/>

bug.short_desc: dtp dependancies should be optional for JST Install

long_desc.thetext: With M4, if I install WTP, EMF, and GEF (but not DTP) I get the following error in the log. I think the dtp dependancy should be listed as optional (and, it's corresponding rdb plugin listed as optional?) ... and the code just be smart enough to know if they are not present (class not found exception) then the things that depend on that would not be enabled. I think this was previously agreed to, and think the code is at least partially written for this, so I'm hoping this is mostly a matter of changing the manifest.

Opps, forgot to paste the console log ...
!MESSAGE Bundle update@plugins/org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ejb.annotations.ui_1.1.1.v200611161506.jar was not resolved. !SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ejb.annotations.ui 2 0 2007-01-06 00:03:56.671 !MESSAGE Missing required bundle org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity_0.0.0. !SUBENTRY 2 org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ejb.annotations.ui 2 0 2007-01-06 00:03:56.671 !MESSAGE Missing required bundle org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.ui.dse_0.0.0.
Raising priority to get attention for M5.

Naci, this issue is now causing big problems if people use the Europa update site to install JST. Even if they say "select required" and some of the DTP features are installed to satisfy this "requirement", then when they restart, they still get a lot of error messages in the log about missing plugins for DTP. While partially DTP's issue, when the same thing happened for JPT, they asked JPT to simply specify that "whole" DTP features be required. And this made since for JPT, but I do not think it does for JST.
The easiest solution would be to mark this requirements as "optional" in the manifest.mf. (and then remove it from the feature.xml).
The only thing I don't know is if the code is bullet proof enough to handle it not being there. I can see that it definitely is in some places, as it's used in try/catch (Throwable) blocks ... [catching throwables will be another bug :) ]
But, I can't quite tell if all cases of "ClassNotfound" would be handled in a relatively friendly way.
Can you confirm please?

Created an attachment (id=71554) minimal patch to fix "required" issue
This patch will "fix" the update manager issues by making DTP optional. I think we _need_ to do this much.
Only question is if we need to add some "try/catch (ClassNotFound) blocks at some strategic locations, or, perhaps we already have enough?

This has to be addressed one way or another ... we either need to "require" all of DTP ... which is not only bad for users who do not use it, but may impact adopters in some unacceptable ways.
Or ... we need to make these few cases of us using it "optional". If its' there, fine, same function, if its not there, fine too we continue with only a teeny tiny function missing.

David,
The CMP wizard from EJB 2.1, uses DTP for connection profiles. I guess we can call DTP optional. It would only disable the CMP wizard. JPA tools also have dependencies on DTP but they are not a part of JST.

I suggest we make DTP optional as described above (and as the patch provides).
That seems better to me that requiring all of DTP as JPT does.
While I'm sure the CMP wizard is very important for some users, seems unreasonable to "require" all users to install DTP.

(In reply to comment #3) > The only thing I don't know is if the code is bullet proof enough to handle >it not being there. But, I can't quite tell if all cases of "ClassNotfound" >would be handled in a relatively friendly way. From an end-user's point of view and esp. for a good out-of-the-box experience, wouldn't it be better to include the entire DTP than risk regressions in features?

(In reply to comment #8) > (In reply to comment #3)
> From an end-user's point of view and esp. for a good out-of-the-box experience, > wouldn't it be better to include the entire DTP than risk regressions in > features? >
Well, it is an extra 20 Meg, so I think many would consider than a worse "out of box" experience. And, it's my impression ... correct me if I'm wrong ... those that would need/be interested in this functionality would know they needed datatools installed too. Everyone else wouldn't see it. And its my impression ... correct me if I'm wrong here too ... that's it's a relatively rare use case?

Oh, and just to emphasize the "size" of this dependency, there are only 3 classes that mention 'datatools' at all. So in general, I hate to have a _hard_ dependency on 20 meg of _anything_ when then there is such a small amount of actual coupling. I was hoping Naci would say if bullet proof or not, its hard for me to know ... but, in my opinon, better to live with that risk that 20 extra meg hard requirement.

It is too late (or scary for me :-) ) to make such a change for Europa. The following classes are affected.
AddContainerManagedEntityEjbWizard.java ChooseTableWizardPage.java ConnectionSelectionPage.java
Short of removing the complete EJB 2.1 CMP tooling as a whole, I do not see a good way of removing the DTP dependency for Europa.
If DTP dependency is critical for an adopter to this pint I guess we can try a solution by RC4

(In reply to comment #11) > I do not see a > good way of removing the DTP dependency for Europa. >
Well, remember, I'm just proposing to make it optional, not remove DTP dependency.
I'll repeat, we need some solution here, so will you be proposing another for us to evaluate?
Have you tried a Europa update site install? Does CMP work, even though there's many error messages in log that DTP is not installed?

David,
We can definitely make it optional. I just have not tested it without DTP to know if it will effect other EJB wizardry (i.e. would it effect non-DTP related things like stateless EJBs)
I will do some testing today without DTP. Past 2.0, I will refactor CMP wizards into a separate plugin. And evaluate alternate methods for connection profiles
Created an attachment (id=71753) Optional DTP dependency

I have attached a patch that makes DTP optional for CMP wizards. I have added a try-catch to the addPages so that other EJB wizards continue to work. A message is added to log for NoClass found exception.
I tested with sans-DTP WTP, things continue to work. CMP wizard disables finish button.
Of course there will be messages in the log
Naci, which JRE did you test this on? A VM using eager classloaders could trigger a NoClassDefFoundError just because IConnectionProfile is in a method signature.
Approved at 6/19 PMC call.
Changes committed v200706191638

I've also released the changes to the feature.xml to remove the 2 'datatools' entries from the 'requires' list.
Eventually, or if someone had time now, we could look into making DTP a true "optional feature" in terms that Update Manager would understand (so user is told it's optional, and given a choice), but I think someone would have to commit to trying/testing that, so perhaps a separate, future enhancement is best for that.

Nitin,
I have used sun jdk1.5.0_06. I have thought this was safe since 3.3 requires Java 5 runtime. Is there a JVM you can suggest for additipnal testing ?
verified on europa updates sites
Verified, closing.

bug.short_desc: Double resource descriptor entries in library.xmi file

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: N20061219-1245
Steps To Reproduce: 1.Create a new lib 2.Create a new plugin 3.Exam the library.xmi file -> there are two resource descriptor entries for the same plugin: <resourceDescriptors xmi:id="_Rl0VsZ1YEdu5OqbKY4O5ew" id="_Rl0VsJ1YEdu5OqbKY4O5ew" uri="new_plug-in/plugin.xmi"/> <resourceDescriptors xmi:id="_Rl0Vsp1YEdu5OqbKY4O5ew" id="_RluPEJ1YEdu5OqbKY4O5ew" uri="new_plug-in/plugin.xmi"/>
This could potententially cause internal errors, and should be fixed.
More information:
The problem also occurs in EPF1.0.2 branch.
2 resourceDescriptors are created when you created new plugin, but only one is valid. This will not cause any issue, but it is trash and should be cleaned up.
In addition to the resource descriptor for new plugin, another resource descriptor is created for its resource manager as well. The later is not needed.
Fix is verified on build label 2007021401.
Fixed verified on EPF1.2 build 20070313-1730. Please close it.
Verified. Closed.

Steps To Reproduce:

More information: Whenever I try to run a unit test with the "JUnit 4" test runner, I get the following error:
---Message--- An internal error occurred during: "Launching". ---
---Exception Stack Trace--- java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ClasspathLocalizer.localURL(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:188) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ClasspathLocalizer.entryString(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:177) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ClasspathLocalizer.addEntry(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:164) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.ClasspathLocalizer.localizeClasspath(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:155) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.createClassPath(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:127) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.createVMRunner(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:54) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.launchTypes(JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.java:159) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.launch(JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.java:98) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:639) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:565) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch(DebugUIPlugin.java:754) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$6.run(DebugUIPlugin.java:944) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58) ---

From the stack trace it looks like your Eclipse installation doesn't contain a plugin 'org.junit4_xxx'. Can you verify this? There should be a plugin yourEclipseInstall\eclipse\plugins\org.junit4_4.1.0.1

bug.short_desc: pre-build .bat file does not run some commands

long_desc.thetext:
I have been trying to use wubscrev with Eclipse/CDT within a pre-build batch file.
During build, the working folder is set to the project folder/build folder
If the batch file is run outside of eclipse from the build folder, it runs OK. If it runs inside of eclipse, it silently fails to exectute subwcrev.
Initially I traced this down to another bug, whereby if the command is at the end of a long PATH Eclipse truncates the PATH.
I copied subwcrev.exe to the project folder and put the following in the batch file. ..\subwcrev.exe ..\. ..\Common\BuildInfo.c.tpl ..\Common\BuildInfo.c
I also tried cd.. subwcrev.exe . Common\BuildInfo.c.tpl common\BuildInfo.c
and cmd /c ..\subwcrev.exe ..\. ..\Common\BuildInfo.c.tpl ..\Common\BuildInfo.c
the following in build steps cmd /c ..\pre.bat ${BuildArtifactFileBaseName}
even this in build steps (which does not work at all) start "Pre Build Tasks" /WAIT cmd /c ..\pre.bat ${BuildArtifactFileBaseName}
It seems certain commands are simply not run without any STDERR or STDIO output indicating why. Adding a pipe > logfile.txt proves this. The file logfile.txt is created, but nothing is ever in it.
I've searched and I can't find the problem mentioned anywhere on the web, so firstly, I need somebody to just confirm that I'm not being stupid somewhere.

Solved the problem!!!
Not a problem with CDT, it was a problem with make.exe
My machine had two copies of make.exe, one earier in the path than the other. It was picking the wrong one for the build, not the one from the cross arm toolchain folder - perhaps there should be some control over which make is being used?
Anyway, the make being used was somehow munging the path when running external commands, thus it could not find subwcrev.exe.
Copying subwcrev.exe to the project folder compouned the problem. Subwcrev could not find its .dll, it normally reports this using a dialogue box, but somehow eclipse was supressing this dialogue.
I solved the problem using a dummy make file that just called the pre.bat, this allowed the dialogue to appear indicating the source of the problem.
Conclusion: I would not consider this bug fixed, there are two possible areas for improvement. 1: Prevent eclipse from supressing dialogue boxes 2: Allow a means to control which make.exe the build uses, just as we can control which gcc or as is used.

bug.short_desc: support viewing and retrieving attachments

long_desc.thetext:
Attachements are not visible from ui. Tested this on 1.0 and 1.0.1 against apache jira instance.
Eclipse Version: 3.3.0

The Jira Connector does not currently support attachments, as these are not supported by the Jira API that we are using (also see bug 165389). For now I have removed the attachments table from the Jira task editor.
Created an attachment (id=57231) mylar/context/zip
At least recent JIRA versions seem to include attachment information in the XML/RSS view of the ticket so there is hope that this can be integrated at some point.

It seems that version 3.8 has fixed the problem, I am not sure.
@ Atlassian
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-11180
@ Jira Dashboard
http://developer.atlassian.com/jira/browse/JDB-10
Hope this helps to get it implemented 4 jira!

Unfortunately the API changes will only be available in JIRA 3.8 and later so we won't be able to use it for the Mylar connector which currently maintains backwards compatibility up to JIRA 3.3.3.
It should be fairly straight forward to enhance the RSS parser to extract attachment information and download attachments from the web interface. Uploading can implemented through SOAP (or through the web interface also).

Steffen: hopefully we should be able to support attachments on 3.8 and later only while maintaining the core functionality backwards compatible. The easiest way to do this is probably to have the attach/retrieve fail with a decent message that says 3.8 or later is needed for this functionality.
Implementing this feature would be greatly increase the collaboration in the www.quickfixj.org open source project.

Implemented attachment support.
Unfortunately JIRA does not support attachment filenames that contain '%' characters so attaching context does not yet work. Also JIRA does not allow a description for an attachment so we will need to rely on the filename to detect contexts.
Created an attachment (id=66015) mylar/context/zip
Added detection code for context attachments that changes the filename to mylar-context.zip.

Wow!
Steffen: could you please file a bug on our use of the URL encoding (% symbols)? We may want to get rid of that in the framework.
Weird. I don't see attachments in the rss feed for this issue https://jira.terracotta.org/jira/browse/CDV-271 I wonder if something need to be enabled somewhere...
Apparently it's missing in the RSS feed. I wonder if attachments have been added in a recent JIRA version (Terracotta uses 3.6.5).
BTW, uploading of attachments is done through the web interface by means of an HTTP POST so it works despite attachments not being displayed in the table.

I noticed that. :-)
BTW, attachments were added to rss in JIRA 3.7...

bug.short_desc: ptp_orte_proxy prebuilt in release org.eclipse.ptp-1.1.0-I200612111900

long_desc.thetext: ptp_orte_proxy and sdm come prebuilt in fragment org.eclipse.ptp.macosx.ppc. The PTP preferences for the ORTE path may have been preset to the macosx.ppc fragment as ORTE fails to startup on macosx.x86 platforms. Removing ptp_orte_proxy from macosx.ppc and changing the ORTE path in preferences fixes the problem.

It's worse than this, because the fragment is being used even though the os and arch do not match. It looks like the code is checking for a 'bin' directory in each fragment and using the first one it finds, rather than checking only in the fragment that matches the os and arch. There's a comment in the code that says:
'First: check for a 'bin' directory in the fragment. This may be an architecture independent fragment.'
I think this was added to deal with the mpich2 proxy which is a python script, not a binary. I'm going to change the code so that the os and arch must match. The python script will need to be copied to the fragrament as part of the BUILD process.
I have implemented these changes. Please reopen if you see this problem again.

bug.short_desc: Problem with BuddyPolicy and fragments

long_desc.thetext:
If you create a fragment F that has a host plug-in H where the fragment registers as a buddy of plugin P, plugin P will not be able to load classes in plug-in H. It only works if plugin H registers itself as a buddy of plugin P.
I can work around the problem by registering the host plug-in as the buddy, but it's a major hack to the design and it kills my flexibility.

Pascal, what are your thoughts on allowing fragments to add buddy policies to thier hosts?
- Should fragments be able to register their hosts as buddies using the Eclipse-RegisterBuddy header?
- What about allowing fragments to add new buddy policies to their hosts using the Eclipse-BuddyPolicy header?
- If we do allow for fragments to define buddy policies and register as buddies then what do we do when fragments are attached to an already resolved HOST? This scenario becomes very complex if we want to allow dynamically attached fragments to modify buddy policies of an already resolved host. If we are going to consider this then I suggest we only do if for fragments that are attached at the same time as their hosts are resolved (i.e. only consider fragments that are currently attached when we setup the PolicyHandler for a bundle).

Here is a live use-case for consideration ...
I have a plug-in that contains EJB 3.0 Entities. I have another plugin that contains all of the hibernate jars for the embedded entity manager. Hibernate needs to be able to class load the entities which requires buddy registering. Since the EJB 3.0 spec is generic, I don't want my plug-in containing entity beans to be dependent on hibernate. My solution was to create a fragment that buddy registers with the hibernate plug-in. This would allow me to easily swap out the hibernate persistence provider with a different one and all I have to do is re-package my product with different fragments to use the new persistence provider.

You can check out the 3.2 branch in to 3.2. Prompted by this request, I have just made this easier via project sets: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_Contributor_Reference#Workspace

I have sort of done the same: downloaded a clean Calypso, updated everything, re-imported all my favorite plug-ins, but no Eclipse PATCHES! I have cleaned up my workspace, split in into several smaller ones, one for each major project. I can download and build the Mylar releases now AND the problem of alternating active editor windows on task activations seems to have gone away because of those steps :-( So creating a repeatable setting solved the problem... I already start Eclipse with -clean every time, maybe its time for a -superclean option ;-)

bug.short_desc: New RCP Wizard / Branding / splash.bmp not exported

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061214-1445
Steps To Reproduce: Create new Hello RCP App.
build.properties is:
source.. = src/ output.. = bin/ bin.includes = plugin.xml,\ META-INF/,\ .,\ icons/
It should be:
source.. = src/ output.. = bin/ bin.includes = plugin.xml,\ META-INF/,\ .,\ icons/,\ splash.bmp

Created an attachment (id=56521) fix
also fixes similar problem in RCP w/ view template
Thanks Sebastian.
released patch.

bug.short_desc: JSP Source Page Editor Takes Very Long To Open and Consumes Large of CPU

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.02
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Copy jsp and jspfs to directories for web project 2. Refresh all projects 3. Open page in Source Page Editor
More information: I copy a large number of jsps and jspfs to my web project for our entire site (RAD6.0 - Eclipse 3.02). I refresh all the projects. When I try to open a jsp or jspf with JSP source page editor, it takes a very long time (more than a few minutes) and consumes 99% of the 2 GB CPU I have. I do not believe this is the lazy initialization of the plugin occuring. There is no error message in the .log file. There are no process (system or otherwise) that are occuring. There is no message displayed. I am not sure if all the JSPs are being refreshed or being validated. I do not have this problem if I use the text editor.

bug.short_desc: Download should alert XP users to the unzip problem

long_desc.thetext: The newsgroups are rife with questions about unzipping the Eclipse SDK download under Windows XP using the ZIP file support built in to the OS. It appears that then problem is related to unzipping to a long directory path - if somehting short like c:\Eclipse is used, the problem seems to be resolved. Also, use of a third-part unzip program seems to avoid the problem. If the Download page included a prominent message alerting the user to this common issue, it would save a lot of people having to track down the answer, save us newsgroup helpers the headache of answering the same questions over and over again, and probably keep some new users from simply giving up on Eclipse before they even have a chance to use it.
Linking this to bug 166597
I think it should be a link to a WIKI page and titled "Known Issues" (or something a long this line).

I've added this message on the downloads page for Windows users only (others will not see it):
Problems extracting the ZIP file? Please read these Known Issues.
Known issues links to a Wiki page.

I think the note about unzip problems is too hidden on the redesigned downloads pages. It should be on http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ instead of buried under "More info..." because I doubt most newbies will ever visit the "More info" page; the main downloads page just makes it too easy to get the ZIP and run. Would it be possible to either put the info directly on http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ or at least a prominent link to the note. See also Bug 196467 that requests a similar note about running on Windows 64-bit. Perhaps a single page with "What you need" and "Common problems" together, either right on the main downloads page or via a prominent link? Re-open this?

(In reply to comment #4) > I think the note about unzip problems is too hidden on the redesigned downloads > pages.
On the old page, if Win32 was the detected OS, the message would appear in bold letters. I think we should re-instate this message, and detect Win64 as well, to add a similar message.

+1
Is the text okay:
http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/moreinfo/parts/windows_zip.php

(In reply to comment #6) > +1 > > Is the text okay: > > http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/moreinfo/parts/windows_zip.php >
I'm not sure if Eclipse Foundation wants to be endorsing WinZip by name. Perhaps it would be better to refer the user to a Google search instead, for example with a URL like http://www.google.com/search?q=free+zip+windows

From the Webmaster inbox: ----------------- In your "note for Windows users" regarding the extraction of the eclipse archives and bugs in the inbuilt windows ZIP support, you link to WinZip as a potential unzipping tool.
Perhaps it would be more in line with the open nature of the EPL to link to an open-source tool like 7-zip (http://7-zip.org/)? I can confirm that it unzips eclipse archives just fine :-) --------------------- -M.

I agree with comment 7 and comment 8. Let's link to 7-zip instead.
Wayne, if you can change your message, I'll then update the download page to add the Win32 detection as it was before.
I've updated the popup window that was existing to point to 7-Zip instead of Winzip.
Fixed as part of bug 200624

bug.short_desc: class name is always reported as empty in new class wizard

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: 1. open the new class wizard in a project (I'm using managed make) 2. enter a name for your class 3. note that it says at the top "class name is empty" and doesn't enable the "finish" button, rendering the class wizard useless 4. the same problem seems to happen to the namespace field
More information: Obviously, the class wizard is 100% useless if you can never make it do anything. Of note: on my machine, typing in the class name and namespace fields is VERY slow (multiple seconds for a single character to appear in the box after being typed). This seems to me to be likely related to whatever validation is going on (and failing). I've used the built-in eclipse update utility to update everything, restarted eclipse a number of times, and even rebooted my computer - this problem persists.
Which version of Linux are you using?

I'm using Fedora Core 5. uname -r: 2.6.18-1.2257.fc5
In the time since my initial posting, I've downloaded a fresh copy of eclipse and installed it; I still have the problem. Since I've never had this problem before, it must have been introduced in a recent update.

bug.short_desc: CVS Repository/Root files incompatible with Gnu (CygWin) CVS

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.1
Steps To Reproduce: CVS workspaces created by the Eclipse "New Project" wizard appear to be incompatible with the GNU CVS client on windows (or, at least, GNU CVS v1.11.17 as provided in CygWin on Windows). Commands fail for frustratingly cryptic reasons, such as the following (including so people searching for these errors will hopefully find this bug)
When doing "cvs login": Logging in to :pserver:anonymous@hello-world.cvs.sourceforge.net:2401/cvsroot/hello-world CVS password: cvs login: authorization failed: server hello-world.cvs.sourceforge.net rejected for user anonymous/hello-world
When doing "cvs some_other_operation" (assuming you've managed to login somehow): cvs status: authorization failed: server hellow-world.cvs.sourceforge.net rejected acc for user anonymous cvs status: used empty password; try "cvs login" with a real password
These errors are caused by Eclipse creating CVS/Repository and CVS/Root files that are improperly terminated by CR+LF instead of just LF (as the CVS protocol seems to require).
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a new project: "File -> New Project -> CVS -> Projects from CVS". I suggest using the following repository (don't worry, it's pretty small): - Host: hello-world.cvs.sourceforge.net - Repository path: /cvsroot/hello-world - User: anonymous - Password: (empty) - Module name: myproject1 - "Checkout as a project in the workspace" 2. Now, from the command line (CygWin on WinXP), cd into the directory for the project you've just created 3. Using cvs v1.11.17 (or so), do "cvs login". Just hit <ENTER> for the password (the anonymous user for this repository doesn't have a password). * You should see an error like the one mentioned above. 4. Fix this by doing the following (remove CR character from CVS/Root): tr -d '\r' < CVS/Root > CVS/Root.new ; mv CVS/Root.new CVS/Root 5. Try "cvs login" again * Logging in should now work(!)
6. Try "cvs status file1" * This command fails 7. Fix this by doing the following (remove CR character from CVS/Repository): tr -d '\r' < CVS/Repository > CVS/Repository.new ; mv CVS/Repository.new CVS/Repository 8. Try "cvs status file1" again * Now it works
... At this point, commands on the top-level files should work but, because the CVS/* files in the subdirectories have not been fixed, commands that relate to those will still fail (e.g. "cvs status new-dir/file1").
More information: A temporary workaround is to run the 'tr' command on all CVS/* files. For example:
for file in `find . | grep "/CVS/"`; do tr -d '\r' < $file > $file.new; mv $file.new $file; done
The recommended fix is to have Eclipse properly terminate all CVS/* files with Unix-style LF characters, rather than windows CR+LF characters.
I am able reproduce this on 3.3M4. Changing version to 3.3.

FYI I don't think the CVS metadata files are expected to be compatible between clients. The advice always seems to be that if you need a different client or operate on files on the same filing system, that you should check out two separate workspaces and sync via the version control system, rather than attempting to use the same one.
Also, I've seen the CVS stuff do weird things with 1.11; generally, the advice is to run on 1.12, though I'm not sure it would address the problem you're highlighting here.
Note that other weird things can happen with different clients e.g. off-by-one-hour errors in summer time because of different processing of the timestamp.
Lastly, it may well be the case that other (windows) native CVS clients (Tortoise CVS e.g.) use CRLF to terminate entries and that applying this fix would result in those not working.
I'm not sure that there is a standard for the Entries (et al) files; the CVS protocol merely says how the client and server talk to each other. It doesn't mandate what that client does, though for some similar compatibility issues they tend to use the same/similar formats.
(This is all IMHO as an external observer, BTW)

Apologies to those I've inconvenienced. It looks like Eclipse already has a solution for this. See the comments about Cygwin here:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/CVS_FAQ#Is_Eclipse_compatible_with_the_command-line_CVS_client.3F

bug.short_desc: Code completion doesn't work icw Logitech Quickcam software

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2
Steps To Reproduce: Install Logitech Quickcam 10.0 (and maybe other versions). They seem to hijack the ctrl-space combination. Simple solution is to close the Logitec Quickcam tray icon.
More information: This is not a bug of eclipse (or maybe there is a possibility to prevent a ctrl-space hijack?), but the main reason I entered it here is, so other people can find a possible reason of why their code completion stopped working or doesn't work. So I am ok if you if you close this immidiately.
Can you describe the "hijack" a bit more? is it just the key combination that does this i.e. does using a different key binding fix the problem? Or is it rather a focus dependent issue?
Get rid of deprecated state.

bug.short_desc: Opening a search result/bug link many times opens multiples editors

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce:
- Make a task search on a bugzilla repository. - Open some search result that is not on task list. - Open it again.
Each time you open it, it opens a new instance of the same editor. It should bring focus to the first opened editor.

I just noted that the same thing happens when you click on a link on bug editor.
Updating the summary to reflect this more generic nature of this bug.
Fixed.
Created an attachment (id=56528) mylar/context/zip

bug.short_desc: Apply Patch action should appear only on patch attachments

long_desc.thetext:
On 3.3 branch there is a very helpful feature to apply a patch directly from attachment table (bug#103932).
However the action appears if you right-click on any attachment. IHMO, it should appear only on attachments whose type is "patch".

Also, it is strange to have it appear after the "Sandbox: Introspect Object" action.
See screenshot on: http://www.jroller.com/page/eu?entry=no_more_excuses_to_not
Perhaps we should move it to the previous group...
-1 for that. There are lots of patches that are attached as a plain text files. Unless, of course, you can detect that plain text file is in fact a patch.

Due to the issue that Eugene points out (lot's of plain text attachments), I don't think that we can do this for the time being because it would prevent being able to apply a significant number of patches. But it does make sense, so I'll mark it for later.
(In reply to comment #1) > Also, it is strange to have it appear after the "Sandbox: Introspect Object" > action.
I moved the action into its own section that we can also use for things like "Retrieve Context". It can't move into the Save... section because that's contributed in code, not via extension point.
Resolving.
Here's the context for the new separator addition.
Created an attachment (id=56859) mylar/context/zip

bug.short_desc: Make "Open corresponding task" more flexible for projects not using Mylyn

long_desc.thetext:
I'll use the platform/team as a example for what I want: they have a policy for CVS comments to something like: "Bug XXXX description".
From this information it should be possible to Mylar to infer the task id, needing only to ask the user what repository it belongs to.

Mylar already does that if this comment match the "Commit Comment Template" in Mylar team settings. Project would have to be linked with Mylar's issue repository from the project preferences. I believe we already have enhancement request to make that template project-specific.
Though, we could show regular open task dialog if repository or template can't be matched, I thing there is a TODO item in the OpenCorrespondingTaskAction...

OK, but I meant make it work with projects NOT using Mylar and consequently not linked to any repository, which is the case for most platform's projects.
Since they use a very simple human-recognizable pattern on CVS comments, I think we can handle this cases without very much effort.

I still believe that Mylar should use that template to extract bug pattern (or maybe extend that default template config to allow several variants that can be used for parsing or chosen for commit comment).
Then we can do what that TODO is suggesting and replace current error dialog with the standard dialog for opening remote tasks...

How about this? * Allow one or more commit comment templates to be specified per-project. If none specified, preference page template is used. * When committing, commit comment template from first selected project is used. If committing to projects with different templates, it is up to the user to commit those projects separately to get the different templates.
Then if resolution still fails we show the open task dialog.

In addition to that it would make sense to allow more then one global template, with one of them marked as default.
BTW, that Team providers have templates too, but does not expose them as api...

(In reply to comment #4) > How about this? > * Allow one or more commit comment templates to be specified per-project. If > none specified, preference page template is used. > * When committing, commit comment template from first selected project is used. > If committing to projects with different templates, it is up to the user to > commit those projects separately to get the different templates. >
Are commit templates used to recognize bug patterns on strings? (sorry, I don't know about how this is done).
I was thinking of something more generic, like a regexp to extract the bug number, no matter how the commit comment is structured.

Willian, it is a little messy right now and in fact it is a mix of both approaches. So, comment template is used, then it can fall back to parsing comment using regexps, delegating actual parsing to connector.

(In reply to comment #7) > Willian, it is a little messy right now and in fact it is a mix of both > approaches. So, comment template is used, then it can fall back to parsing > comment using regexps, delegating actual parsing to connector. >
Sounds good for me.
One thing I missed is that on this case the user will have to be presented to a dialog for repository selection (there is no way to know what repository that bug is for).

Right. In some cases we do know repository but can't identify task id or key, but in some other cases we can identify key, but can't identify repository (i.e. when repository is not assigned to the project). Also see bug 159135
Deferring for 2.0. Willian do you want to take this one?

Strange that it doesn't work. BugzillaConnectorUi.findHyperlinks() does have logic for extracting task ids from the text and I thought that "open corresponding task" is using it. Though there is still an issue with assigning link to the task repository. I think I noticed something like that some time ago, but thought it happens because I've been browsing CVS history, so there were no link to repository.
Anyways, we have some room for improvements, though may need to store some info about linked projects into the repository configuration...

bug.short_desc: GMF Dashboard for EMF

long_desc.thetext:
Dave, Ed, feel free to close this bug as "Crazy idea from ian", or "Why does Ian keep thinking we have time to work on these ideas?" :)
Do you think we could integrate the GMF Dashboard into EMF? There is obviously less tasks in EMF than GMF, but there is still Create Ecore, Derive Genmodel, reload genmodel, generate code, generate editors... You could also put some shortcuts to common tweaks (Generate RCP App from EMF, etc...)
Do you think this may help new users who are just learning EMF?

It doesn't seem so crazy to me, but it's probably not something that we'll have time to work on. I think that, between the tutorials and the cheat sheets, we've made a decent amount of "getting started" information available.
I don't think the basic flow of EMF is that tricky, and I think lots of people get it. Of course, the devil is in the details, which sometimes can provide seemingly endless entertainment, but I don't think a dashboard would help so much with that. I think that writing more documentation would be a better use of our time.
If you or someone else who already groks the big picture wants to contribute this, that would be fantastic.
I doubt we'll ever get to this unless someone contributes it so I'll return it as won't fix.

bug.short_desc: Data set query isn't displayed properly when new a data set [0702]

long_desc.thetext: Data set query isn't displayed properly when new a data set [0702] Build number:2.2.0.v20070108-0630 Steps to reproduce: 1.new a sample DB data dource 2.new a data set and enter "*" behind the "select",then drag the "CUSTOMERS" from "Available Items" view to right behind "from" in the same line Expected result: The query is "select * from CLASSICMODELS.CUSTOMERS " Actual result: The query is "select * fromCLASSICMODELS.CUSTOMERS " you can see the attached image Error log: N/A

It looks as if it is an Eclipse 3.2 - 3.3 compatibility problem. The text cursor sometimes cannot correctly locate to the position as suggested by mouse cursor.
It's a bug of SWT not BIRT, and the fixed code will become available in eclipse's next stable build. Please consider deferring it to the next milestone. Regards
This bug is actually an eclipse swt bug. It can only be fixed after next eclipse milestone is used by BIRT. The bug should be verified by then, and as a temp solution we defer this bug.
Fixed by swt, regards

bug.short_desc: 1 <ENTER> on remote shell view == 2 <ENTER>s

long_desc.thetext:
I'm using Eclipse 3.3 M4 + RSE 2.0 M4.
When I open a SSH shell to a linux machine (my local machine is a Windows XP SP2), each time I hit <ENTER> on the remote shell view, it acts like I have hit <ENTER> 2 times on remote server, i.e. the remote prompt appear 2 times.
I haven't tried with 1.0.1 but I think it will happen too.

This is known and (currently) desired. See bug 162857 comment 1.
The reason is that we send a (hidden) command to query the remote directory, which results in the first prompt. The second prompt is the "real" one.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 162857 ***
